item.title: Sarah added 'Pride and Prejudice'
item.author: Sarah
item.description:
Sarah gave 5 stars to Pride and Prejudice (Paperback) by Jane Austen
bookshelves: classics, 3-stars, school
I love love love Pride and Prejudice. Its dialogue is witty, its plot is entertaining (there's never a dull moment) and the development of Lizzy and Mr. Darcy's love is wonderful. This is my favorite Austen novel particularly because it combines her social commentary with her gorgeous prose and I never felt bored while reading it.

item.title: Ilya added 'An Absolutely Remarkable Thing'
item.author: Ilya
item.description:
Ilya gave 5 stars to An Absolutely Remarkable Thing (An Absolutely Remarkable Thing, #1) by Hank Green
Oh my. I just want to exist in this world for a bit longer, so I guess I'm part of the masses of people clamoring for the sequel now!

I've known of Hank Green ever since discovering his and his brother's podcast, Dear Hank and John, about a year and a half ago. Of course that's also where I heard about his debut novel, so into the reading list it went.

And I'm so glad that it did! I think I'll need to be a little bit more than five minutes after finishing the novel to really articulate what grabbed me so much about this story but in between reading a huge chunk on the plane yesterday and finishing it today, I would think about it while just sitting around.

Wonderful story aside, I enjoyed the examination of what it's like to be thrust into the position of being a public figure, of our modern Internet culture, and of what it's like to reimagine yourself not as a human but as a brand. I suspect this was a little bit autobiographical on Hank's part.

Side note: when you see an Amazon link in the book, I recommend entering it into your browser. You'll laugh, shake your head, and go "oh Hank".
